creator: arduinoenigma
title: Enigma QR Clock
materials_required: Seeed Studios 2.8'' TFT Touch Shield V2.0 (SLD10261P)
description: The Enigma QR Clock project involves building a clock that displays the time as a rapidly changing QR code on a Seeed LCD touchscreen using an Arduino Uno. By optimizing the QR generation and using a fast TFT library, the clock can display seconds. The time can be set manually or automatically using a computer.
steps: Assemble the hardware by plugging the Seeed Studios 2.8'' TFT Touch Shield V2.0 on top of the Arduino Uno.

Download the Fast TFT Library (PDQ_ILI9341 LCD controller by XarkLabs) from https://github.com/arduinoenigma/FastSeedTFTv2/archive/master.zip and install it using the Arduino IDE (Sketch -> Include Library -> Add .ZIP Library).

Download the QR Clock Program (Arduino sketch) from https://github.com/arduinoenigma/EnigmaQRClock/archive/master.zip, create a folder named EnigmaQRClock in your Arduino Sketch folder, and unzip the contents of the zip file into it. Open the EnigmaQRClock.ino file in the Arduino IDE.

Upload the clock program to the Arduino Uno.  If using an Adafruit screen, comment out #define TFTSeed and uncomment //#define TFTAdafruit. Select the correct board and port in the Arduino IDE. Upload the sketch (Sketch -> Upload or Ctrl + U).

Set the time by opening the Serial Monitor (Tools -> Monitor or Ctrl + Shift + M), ensuring the speed is set to 9600 baud, and typing a command like i0;r1;h15;m22;s25;u10;d;x; to set the color scheme, rotation, hours, minutes, seconds, update rate, show the time, and start the clock.

Alternatively, set the time automatically by editing the setclock.cmd file (setting the EnigmaQRPort to the correct serial port number) and double-clicking it. First, open and close the Serial Monitor in the Arduino IDE to open the port.
Optionally, add a protective case to the project using the case at the link below: http://www.ponoko.com/design-your-own/products/enigma-case-w-2-logos-clear-scratch-resistant-acrylic-12383
